place.name: DIDSBURY
place.gazetteerText: DIDSBURY, a township-chapelry and a sub-district, in Chorlton district, Lancashire. The chapelry is in Manchester parish; was constituted in 1838; lies on the river Mersey, at the boundary with Cheshire, 3 miles W of Stockport; and has a post office under Manchester. Acres, 1, 527. Real property, £13, 116. Pop., 1,829. Houses, 364. The property is much subdivided. Didsbury House is a chief residence. There are large cotton factories. The living is a rectory in the diocese of Manchester. Value, £180.* Patrons, Trustees. The church is old but very good; and has a tower. There is a Wesleyan Methodist College. There are also schools with £51 from endowment; and other charities with £17.—The sub-district contains also three other townships. Acres, 5, 948. Pop., 5, 904. Houses, 978. (In 1870-72, John Marius Wilson's Imperial Gazetteer of England and Wales)

unit.name: DIDSBURY CHRIST CHURCH BARLOW MOOR ROAD
